column1: The first recorded inhabitants of the Milwaukee area are the Algonquin and Siouan peoples. French Catholic Jesuits
column2: who ministered to Native Americans and fur traders
column3: were the first Europeans to pass through the area. In 1818
column4: the French Canadian explorer Solomon Juneau established a permanent settlement
column6: Juneau's town combined with two neighboring towns to incorporate as the city of Milwaukee. Large numbers of German immigrants arrived during the late 1840s

column1: In the mid twentieth century large numbers of African Americans moved to Milwaukee from southern states for work during the Great Migration.  African Americans from Chicago descended from those who were part of the Great Migration  have continued to move to the north side of Milwaukee since then.  Milwaukee's east side has attracted a population of Russians and other Eastern Europeans who began migrating in the 1990's after the end of the Cold War.  Many Hispanics of mostly Puerto Rican and Mexican heritage live on the south side of Milwaukee.

column3: a group of "Ojibwas and Pottawattamies from the far [Lake] Michigan" (i.e.

column6: the Native Americans fought the United States in the Northwest Indian War as part of the Council of Three Fires. During the War of 1812
column7: they held a council in Milwaukee in June 1812
column8: which resulted in their decision to attack Chicago in retaliation against American expansion. This resulted in the Battle of Fort Dearborn on August 15
column10: the only known armed conflict in the Chicago area. This battle convinced the American government that the Native Americans had to be removed from their land. After being attacked in the Black Hawk War in 1832
column11: the Native Americans in Milwaukee signed the Treaty of Chicago with the United States in 1833. In exchange for their ceding their lands in the area
column12: they were to receive monetary payments and lands west of the Mississippi in Indian Territory.

column1: Milwaukee began to grow as a city as high numbers of immigrants
column2: mainly German
column3: made their way to Wisconsin during the 1840s and 1850s. Scholars classify German immigration to the United States in three major waves
column4: and Wisconsin received a significant number of immigrants from all three. The first wave from 1845 to 1855 consisted mainly of people from Southwestern Germany
column5: the second wave from 1865 to 1873 concerned primarily Northwestern Germany
column6: while the third wave from 1880 to 1893 came from Northeastern Germany. In the 1840s
column7: the number of people who left German-speaking lands was 385
column9: in the 1850s it reached 976
column11: and an all-time high of 1.4 million immigrated in the 1880s. In 1890
column12: the 2.78 million first-generation German Americans represented the second-largest foreign-born group in the United States. Of all those who left the German lands between 1835 and 1910
column13: 90 percent went to the United States
column14: most of them traveling to the Mid-Atlantic states and the Midwest.By 1900 34 percent of Milwaukee's population was of German background. The largest number of German immigrants to Milwaukee came from Prussia
column18: and Hesse-Darmstadt. Milwaukee gained its reputation as the most German of American cities not just from the large number of German immigrants it received
column19: but for the sense of community which the immigrants established here.Most German immigrants came to Wisconsin in search of inexpensive farmland. However
column20: immigration began to change in character and size in the late 1840s and early 1850s
column21: due to the 1848 revolutionary movements in Europe. After 1848
column22: hopes for a united Germany had failed
column25: turned their attention to the United States.One of the most famous "liberal revolutionaries" of 1848 was Carl Schurz. He later explained in 1854 why he came to Milwaukee

column1: It is true, similar things [cultural events and societies] were done in other cities where the Forty-eighters  [sic] had congregated. But so far as I know, nowhere did their influence so quickly impress itself upon the whole social atmosphere as in 'German Athens of America' as Milwaukee was called at the time.

Schurz was referring to the various clubs and societies Germans developed in Milwaukee. The pattern of German immigrants to settle near each other encouraged the continuation of the German lifestyle and customs. This resulted in German language organizations that encompassed all aspects of life; for example
column2: singing societies and gymnastics clubs. Germans also had a lasting influence on the American school system. Kindergarten was created as a pre-school for children
column3: and sports programs of all levels
column4: as well as music and art were incorporated as elements of the regular school curriculum. These ideas were first introduced by radical-democratic German groups
column5: such as the Socialist Turner Societies
column6: known today as the American Turners. Specifically in Milwaukee
column7: the American Turners established its own Normal College for teachers of physical education and a German-English Academy.Milwaukee's German element is still strongly present today. The city celebrates its German culture by annually hosting a German Fest in July and an Oktoberfest in October. Milwaukee boasts a number of German restaurants
column8: as well as a traditional German beer hall. A German language immersion school is offered for children in grades K-5.

column1: One of the distinctive traits of Milwaukee's residential areas are the neighborhoods full of so-called Polish flats. These are two-family homes with separate entrances
column2: but with the units stacked one on top of another instead of side-by-side. This arrangement enables a family of limited means to purchase both a home and a modestly priced rental apartment unit. Since Polish-American immigrants to the area prized land ownership
column3: this solution
column4: which was prominent in their areas of settlement within the city

column1: The tallest building in the city is the U.S. Bank Center.
Milwaukee's location in the Great Lakes Region often has rapidly changing weather
column2: producing a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa)
column3: with cold
column4: windy
column6: and warm
column7: humid summers. The warmest month of the year is July
column8: when the 24-hour average is 71.8 °F (22.1 °C)
column9: while January is the coldest month
column10: with a 24-hour average of 22.3 °F (−5.4 °C).Because of Milwaukee's proximity to Lake Michigan
column11: a convection current forms around mid-afternoon in light wind
column12: resulting in the so-called "lake breeze" – a smaller scale version of the more common sea breeze. The lake breeze is most common between the months of March and July. This onshore flow causes cooler temperatures to move inland usually 5 to 15 miles (8 to 24 km)
column13: with much warmer conditions persisting further inland. Because Milwaukee's official climate site
column15: is only 3 miles (4.8 km) from the lake
column16: seasonal temperature variations are less extreme than in many other locations of the Milwaukee metropolitan area.

column2: the convection current reverses and an offshore flow ensues causing a land breeze. After a land breeze develops
column3: warmer temperatures flow east toward the lakeshore
column4: sometimes causing high temperatures during the late evening. The lake breeze is not a daily occurrence and will not usually form if a southwest
column6: or northwest wind generally exceeds 15 mph (24 km/h). The lake moderates cold air outbreaks along the lakeshore during winter months.

column2: overnight lows in downtown Milwaukee year-round are often much warmer than suburban locations because of the urban heat island effect. Onshore winds elevate daytime relative humidity levels in Milwaukee as compared to inland locations nearby.

column1: Thunderstorms in the region can be dangerous and damaging

column4: almost all summer rainfall in the city is brought by these storms. In spring and fall
column6: lighter rain bring most of the precipitation. A moderate snow cover can be seen on or linger for many winter days
column8: on average
column9: over 40% of days see less than 1 inch (2.5 cm) on the ground.Milwaukee tends to experience highs that are 90 °F (32 °C) on or above seven days per year
column10: and lows at or below 0 °F (−18 °C) on six to seven nights. Extremes range from 105 °F (41 °C) set on July 24
column12: 1982 and February 4
column15: featured temperatures as low as −40 °F (−40 °C) in some of the suburbs as little as 10 miles (16 km) to the north of Milwaukee.

column1: According to the United States' Environmental Protection Agency
column2: Milwaukee is threatened by ongoing climate change which is warming the planet. These risk include worsened heat waves because many of its residents do not possess air conditioners
column3: concerns about the water quality of Lake Michigan
column4: and increased chances of flooding from intense rainstorms. In 2018

column6: despite the United States' withdrawal
column7: and set a goal moving a quarter of the city's electricity sources to renewable energy by 2025. These have included expansions in the city's solar power-generating capacity and a wind turbine's installation near the Port of Milwaukee. Other actions being taken include local incentives for energy-saving upgrades to homes and businesses.

column2: Lake Michigan experienced large algae blooms
column3: which can threaten aquatic life. Responding to this problem
column4: in 2009 the city became an "Innovating City" in the Global Compact Cities Program. The Milwaukee Water Council was also formed in 2009. Its objectives were to "better understand the processes related to freshwater systems dynamics" and to develop "a policy and management program aimed at balancing the protection and utilization of freshwater". The strategy used the Circles of Sustainability method. Instead of treating the water quality problem as a single environmental issue
column5: the Water Council draws on the Circles method to analyze the interconnection among ecological
column6: economic
column7: political and cultural factors. This holistic water treatment helped Milwaukee win the US Water Alliance's 2012 US Water Prize.

column1: Milwaukee's founding fathers had a vision for the city: they knew it was perfectly situated as a port city
column2: a center for collecting and distributing produce. Many of the new immigrants who were pouring into the new state of Wisconsin during the middle of the 19th century were wheat farmers. By 1860
column3: Wisconsin was the second ranked wheat-growing state in the country and Milwaukee shipped more wheat than any place in the world. Railroads were needed to transport all this grain from the wheat fields of Wisconsin to Milwaukee's harbor. Improvements in railways at the time made this possible.

column1: There was intense competition for markets with Chicago
column2: and to a lesser degree
column3: with Racine and Kenosha. Eventually Chicago won out due to its superior financial and transposition status
column4: as well as being a hub on major railroad lines throughout the United States. Milwaukee did solidify its place as the commercial capital of Wisconsin and an important market in the Midwest.

column4: rendering plants

column1: Reshaping of the valley began with the railroads built by city co-founder Byron Kilbourn to bring product from Wisconsin's farm interior to the port. By 1862 Milwaukee was the largest shipper of wheat on the planet
column2: and related industry developed. Grain elevators were built and
column3: due to Milwaukee's dominant German immigrant population
column4: breweries sprang up around the processing of barley and hops. A number of tanneries were constructed

column1: Milwaukee has a mayor-council form of government. With the election of Mayor John O. Norquist in 1988
column2: the city adopted a cabinet form of government with the mayor appointing those department heads not otherwise elected or appointed—notably the Fire and Police Chiefs. While this gave the mayor greater control of the day-to-day operations of the city
column3: the Common Council retains almost complete control over the city's finances and the mayor
column4: with the exception of his proposed annual budget
column5: cannot directly introduce legislation. The Common Council consists of 15 members
column6: one from each district in the city. Milwaukee has a history of giving long tenures to its mayors; from Frank Zeidler to current mayor Tom Barrett
column7: the city has had only four mayors in the last 60 years. When 28-year incumbent Henry Maier retired in 1988
column8: he held the record for longest term of service for a city of Milwaukee's size.

column1: In addition to the election of a Mayor and Common Council on the city level

column1: Milwaukee has been a Democratic stronghold for more than a century at the federal level. At the local level
column2: Socialists frequently won the mayorship and (for briefer periods) other city and county offices during much of the first sixty years of the 20th century. The city is split between seven state Senate districts
column3: each of which is composed of three Assembly districts. All but four state legislators representing the city are Democrats; the four Republicans—two in the State Assembly and two in the State Senate—represent outer portions of the city that are part of districts dominated by heavily Republican suburban counties. In 2008
column4: Barack Obama won Milwaukee with 77% of the vote. Tim Carpenter (D)

column12: JoCasta Zamarripa (D)
column25: and Mike Kuglitsch (R) represent Milwaukee in the Wisconsin State Assembly.

column1: Milwaukee makes up the overwhelming majority of Wisconsin's 4th congressional district. The district is heavily Democratic. The Democratic primary for the seat is considered more important than the general election. The district is currently represented by Democrat Gwen Moore. A Republican has not represented a significant portion of Milwaukee in Congress since Charles J. Kersten lost his seat in the 5th district in 1954 to Democrat Henry S. Reuss. The small portions of the city extending into Waukesha and Washington counties are part of the 5th District
column2: represented by Republican Jim Sensenbrenner.

column1: Three of Wisconsin's Interstate highways intersect in Milwaukee. Interstate 94 (I-94) comes north from Chicago to enter Milwaukee and continues west to Madison. The stretch of I-94 from Seven Mile Rd. to the Marquette Interchange in Downtown Milwaukee is known as the North-South Freeway. I-94 from Downtown Milwaukee west to Wisconsin 16 is known as the East-West Freeway.

I-43 enters Milwaukee from Beloit in the southwest and continues north along Lake Michigan to Green Bay via Sheboygan and Manitowoc. I-43 southwest of I-41/I-894/US 41/US 45 Hale Interchange is known as the Rock Freeway. I-43 is cosigned with I-894 East and I-41/US 41 South to I-94 is known as the Airport Freeway. At I-94
column2: I-43 follows I-94 to the Marquette Interchange. I-43 continues north known as the North-South Freeway to Wisconsin Highway 57 near Port Washington.
Interstate 41 follows I-94 north from the state line before turning west at the Mitchell Interchange to the Hale Interchange and then north to Green Bay via Fond du Lac
column3: Oshkosh and Appleton. I-41/US 41/US 45 from the Hale Interchange to Wisconsin Hwy 145 is known as the Zoo Freeway.

column1: Milwaukee has two auxiliary Interstate Highways
I-894 bypasses Downtown Milwaukee on the west and south sides of the city from the Zoo Interchange to the Mitchell Interchange. I-894 is part of the Zoo Freeway and the Airport Freeway.
I-794 extends east from the Marquette Interchange to Lake Michigan before turning south over the Hoan Bridge toward Milwaukee Mitchell International Airport
column2: turning into Highway 794 along the way. This is known as the Lake Freeway.

column2: the Milwaukee area was ranked the 4th best city for commuters by Forbes.
Port of Milwaukee
column3: handled 2.4 million metric tons of cargo through its municipal port in 2014. Steel and salt are handled at the port.

column2: Michigan through the Lake Express high-speed auto and passenger ferry. The Lake Express travels across Lake Michigan from late spring to the fall of each year.

column1: Milwaukee has over 105 miles (169 km) of bicycle lanes and trails
column2: most of which run alongside or near its rivers and Lake Michigan. The Oak Leaf Trail
column3: a multi-use recreational trail
column4: provides bicycle trails throughout the city and county. Still pending are the creation of bicycle lanes along major commuting routes
column5: such as the Hoan Bridge connector between downtown and the suburbs to the south. The city has also identified over 250 miles (400 km) of streets on which bike lanes will fit. It has created a plan labeling 145 miles (233 km) of those as high priority for receiving bike lanes. As part of the city's Bicycle and Pedestrian Task Force's mission to "make Milwaukee more bicycle and pedestrian friendly"
column6: over 700 bike racks have been installed throughout the city. The Bicycle Federation of Wisconsin holds an annual Bike to Work Week. The event
column8: has frequently featured a commuter race between a car
column9: a bus
column10: and a bike; and also a morning ride into work with the mayor. In 2006
column11: Milwaukee obtained bronze-level status from the League of American Bicyclists
column12: a rarity for a city its size.In 2009
column13: the Milwaukee County Transit System began installing bicycle racks to the front of county buses. This "green" effort was part of a settlement of an asbestos lawsuit leveled by the state at the county in 2006. The lawsuit cites the release of asbestos into the environment when the Courthouse Annex was demolished.In August 2014
column14: Milwaukee debuted a bicycle sharing system called Bublr Bikes
column15: which is a partnership between the City of Milwaukee and a local non-profit Midwest Bike Share (dba Bublr Bikes). As of September 2016
column16: the system operates 39 stations throughout downtown
column18: and the UW-Milwaukee campus area and near downtown neighborhoods. The City of Milwaukee installed another ten Bublr Bikes stations in October 2016
column19: and the adjacent suburb of Wauwatosa installed eight stations in September 2016
column20: which will bring the system size to 58 stations by the end of 2016. More stations are scheduled for installation in the Village of Shorewood and the City of West Allis in 2017. Future system expansion in the City of Milwaukee is also expected as the City was awarded a second federal Congestion Mitigation/Air Quality (CMAQ) program grant ($1.9 million) to add more stations starting in 2018.

column1: A 2015 study by Walk Score ranked Milwaukee as the 15th most walkable out of the 50 largest U.S. cities. As a whole
column2: the city has a score of 62 out of 100. However
column3: several of the more densely populated neighborhoods have much higher scores: Juneautown has a score of 95; the Lower East Side has a score of 91; Yankee Hill scored 91; and the Marquette and Murray Hill neighborhoods both scored 89 each. Those ratings range from "A Walker's Paradise" to "Very Walkable."

column1: According to the 2016 American Community Survey
column2: 71% of working city of Milwaukee residents commuted by driving alone
column3: 10.4% carpooled
column4: 8.2% used public transportation
column5: and 4.9% walked. About 2% used all other forms of transportation
column6: including taxicab
column8: and bicycle. About 3.4% of working city of Milwaukee residents worked at home. In 2015
column9: 17.9% of city of Milwaukee households were without a car
column10: which increased to 18.7% in 2016. The national average was 8.7 percent in 2016. Milwaukee averaged 1.3 cars per household in 2016
column11: compared to a national average of 1.8 per household.

column8: which includes a lakefront spur connecting the line to the proposed $122 million
column9: 44-story Couture. Construction on the Milwaukee Streetcar began March 2017
column10: with initial operation by mid-2018. The Lakefront service is expected to start operation by 2019.Northwestern Mutual Tower and Commons stands 550 feet (170 m) tall and has 32 stories
column11: making it the second tallest building in Milwaukee.Fiserv Forum
column12: a new multipurpose arena located at 1111 Vel R. Phillips Avenue
column13: has been built to accommodate the Milwaukee Bucks and Marquette Golden Eagles. Construction on the $524 million project began in November 2015 and opened to the public on August 26
column14: 2018. The arena is intended to be the focal point of a "live block" zone that includes public space surrounded by both commercial and residential developments. The arena has a transparent facade and a curved roof and side that is meant to evoke the water forms of nearby Lake Michigan and the Milwaukee River.
